title: Lab 1: FPGA and MCU Setup and Testing
text:
In this lab, a design was implemented on the FPGA to demonstrate the functionality of the on-board high-speed oscillator, DIP switches, and a 7-segment display. The high speed oscillator was configured with a frequency of 24 MHz and divided with a counter to blink an LED at a frequency of 2.4Hz. 4 DIP switches represented a binary input that was used to drive a 7-segment display to show that binary value’s hexadecimal representation.
This lab is completely Excellent!
I spent about 32 hours on this lab.

title: Lab 1: FPGA and MCU Setup and Testing
text:
In this lab, a design was implemented on the FPGA to demonstrate the functionality of the on-board high-speed oscillator, DIP switches, and a 7-segment display. The high speed oscillator was configured with a frequency of 24 MHz and divided with a counter to blink an LED at a frequency of 2.4Hz. 4 DIP switches represented a binary input that was used to drive a 7-segment display to show that binary value’s hexadecimal representation.
This lab is completely Excellent!
I spent about 32 hours on this lab.

title: Lab 1: FPGA and MCU Setup and Testing
text:
Design and Testing Methodology
The HSOSC onboard the FPGA was configured to operate at 24MHz, and divided with a counter to 5M to make the LED blink every 1/2.4 seconds, i.e. 2.4Hz. A clock divider was created in the top module.
The LEDs soldered onto the board were used. LED2 was the oscillating one, while LED0 and LED1 were toggled using combinational logic where LED0 = s0^s1, and LED1 = s2&s3.
The 7 segment display was placed on a breadboard with a 3.3V source,1kΩ current limiting resistors leading to ground at the FPGA pins. Combinational logic was used to translate the binary from the switches to specific combinations of LED segments that would display 0-f.

title: Lab 1: FPGA and MCU Setup and Testing
text:
Technical Documentation
The source code for the project can be found in the associated Github repository.

title: Lab 1: FPGA and MCU Setup and Testing
text:
Block Diagram
Joshua Heinstein, 9/4/2025  The block diagram in figure 1 shows the general architecture of the design for lab 1. The top module includes the 7 segment display module, and it also contains the oscillator, counter, and a couple floating gates to drive 2 of the LEDs.

title: Lab 1: FPGA and MCU Setup and Testing
text:
Schematic
Joshua Heinstein, 9/4/2025 
The schematic in figure 2 shows the physical design of the circuit. Each segment of the display was powered by a 3.3v source, passed through the LED then a current-limiting resistor, and grounded through the FPGA pins to be able to choose which LEDs were on at a given time by allowing current to flow.

title: Lab 1: FPGA and MCU Setup and Testing
text:
Resistor Calculations
 The calculations for resistor values to provide appropriate amounts of current are shown here.

title: Lab 1: FPGA and MCU Setup and Testing
text:
Results and Discussion

Testbench Simulation
 Top module simulation  sevseg module simulation
The design met all intended design objectives. I was able to complete a Questasim simulation with test vectors for both the top and sevseg modules, and they both passed all test cases.

title: Lab 1: FPGA and MCU Setup and Testing
text:
Conclusion
My design was able to blink an LED at 2.4Hz, light 2 LEDs with combinational logic from system inputs, and use combinational logic to translate between binary input values and a hexadecimal display output.

title: Lab 1: FPGA and MCU Setup and Testing
text:
AI Prototype

Yielded error: Error 35901063 Synthesis ERROR <35901063> - c:/users/jheinstein/desktop/microp/lab1/aiproj/source/impl_1/ai.sv(16): instantiating unknown module SB_HFOSC. VERI-1063 [ai.sv:16]
GPT said to use this code:

It kept generating the same error codes.
ChatGPT was clearly unable to realize it did the exact same thing that was causing the problem in the first attempt. This makes it frustrating to use LLMs for this type of work because you can tell it exactly what is wrong and it will keep doing the same wrong thing. The quality of this output is quite low because it didn’t work and didn’t get any better. I was not familiar with the way it wanted to instantiate the clock. The LLM generated code did not synthesize because the core way it is trying to generate the clock is not working. Next time, I might think about using the LLM to find a specific issue I have rather than starting from scratch and having it generate me a completely wrong thing.

title: E155 Portfolio
text:
I’m Joshua Heinstein and I am a senior studying Electrical Engineering at Harvey Mudd College. This semester I am taking Microprocessor-based systems, and I will be documenting my work on this page. I am also working on a robotic system for XDemics Corporation’s bioreactors through Mudd’s clinic program. I find digital electronics and robotics exciting, and I look forward to sharing my work here.
Outside of my schoolwork, my hobbies include skiing, lifting, listening to music, and messing with old audio equipment.
I also love my bird

title: Lab 1 Blog
text: My initial blog post is about what I’m hoping to get out of MicroPs. I am excited by the possibilities of what I can accomplish by learning how to create embedded systems. I am looking forward to learning how to influence the physical world from the digital domain. I have heard of many cool MicroPs final projects throughout my time at Mudd, and I can’t wait to work on a project of my own! I am really hoping to keep an efficient work schedule so I can learn everything this course has to offer, and effectively apply this learning to my clinic project working on a robotic system for XDemics’ bioreactor.
